There is no organization
for plan today. Everybody gets to participate
at the level they wish.

And I came with no real agenda. I could talk about
Carl for quite a while.

But I don't see a need for it. Most of the people here know
him by reputation if not

by in person. He was a common
fixture at EE-380.

And so I think that
what we should do is just talk a
little bit about Carl

and his contributions, what
it is that he actually did. And if there are students in our
audience, which there should be,

if you have questions about Carl
and what his contributions were, ask him of this group
because these people know.

Well, I came with a question. But I don't know if I
should start it off. You're the one to
start it off on.

Carl had this very
simple three line proof that purportedly contradicted
one of Godel's theorems,

the one about
mathematics not being able to prove its consistency.

And this proof proved
mathematics consistency.

And I wonder if
anybody had any ideas

about that, what they think
about it, do they believe it.

Well, we all we
can prove anything if we have the right assumption. Hold on.

Do they believe it do? If they do, what is
the significance of it?
Or how to understand it. OK, go ahead.

The comment was making is that
you can prove anything if you have the right assumptions.

What is the proof? I was afraid somebody
is going to ask me that.

It's in his book. I always forget it
every time I hear it.
But it's-- I don't know. Dennis, do it by heart?

No, I don't. It's something like this. But I'm afraid I
might make a mistake. It's something like, it's
proof by contradiction.

So if you want to prove
that mathematics proves

its own consistency,
then you assume that it doesn't prove
its own consistency. And then at the end-- and
then you have another line,

and I forget what that is. At the end, you
have p and not p, which is false, which means
the premise is proved.

It goes something like that. But I might-- I'm sure
I'm leaving things out. And I'm not a logician.

But it's in the his book the
Inconsistency Robustness book.

Well, to paraphrase
John McCarthy, I'm in no position
to call his bluff.

But I did go to a
seminar where he talked

about that kind of thing. And I remember arguing
against some things he did. And he argued back.

And I wasn't convinced
by his argument. But now I don't remember
what the details were.

But I don't remember anyone
ever saying, oh, I understand it

and he's right. Yes. He explained it several
times in the FRIM sessions.

The point I took was
that the logic system has to accept p and not p.

And if it does,
then you can prove that mathematics is consistent. And so he was saying
that Godel's premises

were incomplete. Now that's as much
understanding as I have of it.

I think-- I am
reminded of John Rush's proofs of the existence of God
or the non-existence of god.

And you can prove anything
if you set it up right.

Well, he also used-- or he also proved
in addition to that

the Russell's-- the
Russell's paradox sentence,

the I am not proof, or
whatever the sentence is, that Godel used could not
be-- should not be allowed.

The self-referential sentence
cannot be allowed because it

jumps levels, basically. Right. He was-- he was always-- I think, as I recall,
he connected it

to second order logic. The first order logic
is not sufficient.
Right. That is correct. Something like that.

So does anybody
believe the proof? He never convinced me. But he was so much smarter.

I really couldn't
argue with him.
OK. But I think--

I think he convinced me
that he was on to something. But I think that so
much of mathematics

depends upon things
that he was perfectly willing to toss out on the--

out of the hamper. Maybe we need to rethink
things and refine definitions

a little bit before
we go throwing out the baby with the bathwater.

I think he didn't accept
Tarskian semantics. So what he meant
by validity might

be different from what
logicians would take it to be.

Carl had a habit of
using terminology to mean something other than
what everybody else thought
it meant.

And maybe everybody else
didn't have a consistent view of what it meant. That's probably true too.

The nice part about Carl
attending the Friday meeting was

we had two hours, when we
were meeting physically of, in the room, being able
to question him in detail

and push him on the details. So we may have gotten more
coherent explanation than many.

I don't know that any of
us fully understood him on many of these points. But we did have the opportunity.

We tried out quite a
few new ideas on us. And I thought that was
always interesting.

I found myself arguing
with him on various issues. But the issue was
usually definitional

because his definitions were a
little bit awkwardly different from what everybody else
thought was the way it was done.

And I keep coming back
to my earlier remark. You can always prove
almost anything

if you have the right
set of assumptions. Which may be false.

Well, I think, in
the book, he argues how his assumptions are all
pretty standard because I

looked it up this morning. I mean, I don't
know that they are.

But he states that I
make this assumption and that's pretty-- you know,
and he has some references.

And it's pretty well
understood that this is it. And this assumption,
this is kind of standard,

and that's standard. So he does make-- he does try to
make a case that the definitions

and assumptions he's
using are kind of standard and widely used.

To some extent, I
thought he lived

within his own virtual
logical reality. So he did bend things a
little bit here and there.
He had his own distortion field. Yeah. Exactly.

Who doesn't? Well, most of us live in
our own virtual reality. That's not a surprise.

Yeah. And sometimes we do it
subconsciously without knowing

that we're doing it.  But I think the
important thing was

Carl was trying to
solve deep problems.

And he wasn't
afraid of criticism. Yeah. People didn't understand him. He didn't get angry.

He just explained. Now the explanation may
not have been any better than the original one,
but he kept trying.

He seemed to have
infinite patience with people who didn't get
what he was talking about.

And even people with
no credentials like me.

I have no training
in computer science. My background, I have
a PhD in astronomy.

I tell people I learned
computer science the way I learned about sex, on the
street corner from my friends.

And Carl was always
very patient with me. And he was always trying to
fill in the gaps in my knowledge

so that I could
understand him better. He definitely was not a snob. If I said something stupid, he
didn't just walk away from me.

He explained why I was
wrong and then continued with his incomprehensible
descriptions.

Yeah. Where were you in
contact with him? At the FRIM meeting.

FRIM. OK. For several, several
years, I don't know, three or four years at least,
he was a regular attendee.

And he always had a paper
that he was about to give. And he wanted to
do a dry run on it.

Right. He often did that. And we always told him his
slides had too many colors

and too many fonts. I always told him that. I told him that
he made everything
too bright and too sharp. And it was distracting.

Yes. He should simplify it. And I told him over, and
over, and over again. And he didn't take
it into account.

He was like incapable of getting
rid of all these blaring colors and fonts.

And squiggles and squaggles. He often and asked me
to review his slides.

Yeah. And I am very careful about the
flow, the story I'm telling,

a talk is a story. And it has to flow. And he did take my suggestions
on improving the flow

on several of his talks. So I felt like I
contributed something. He always gave me-- he gave
me his slides to review.

And sometimes, he would tone
down the fonts and the colors. But then in the next
iteration, they would be back.

I never succeeded
on fonts and colors. But I did get him to
do some reorganization

so he was telling the story
more clearly, I thought. Yeah. He had a habit of-- I think there was
specific feedback

he was seeking on particular
aspects of things. And he just filtered out
anything that wasn't fact.

And he was very good
not listening to you. And I think that
was part of what

let him focus on these sort
of deep, deep abstraction.

Not listening and making
you think he is listening. Well, no, no, it was like, I
had lots of wonderful arguments

with him, both at FRIM and he-- when I was working
at PayPal, he somehow

developed the habit of
inviting himself over for lunch every week or two. And then I'd end up spending the
afternoon arguing or something

with him. And it was like, if the thing
that you were focusing on

was the thing that
he was focusing on, then you could have
these amazingly fruitful

conversations. And if the thing that he was
focusing on was something and you were seeing some
other thing off to the side,

he would just be like, he
just wouldn't hear you. Focus.

I remember one
talk he gave where I asked a question
about one of the axioms,

I thought it was different
from one of his earlier axioms.

And he changed it on
the slide without-- I wasn't actually saying
it was wrong, just saying

it could have been-- asking why it was that way. But he just changed it
without worrying about

whether what this did to
the rest of his system. He just was--

He didn't care about
consistency, Richard. He didn't mind. He didn't mind inconsistency.

Well, he had this way of looking
at long standing problems

in a completely different way. There was a system
where you're going

to have several
communicating components in this particular model
called object capabilities.

And when they're
distributed, there's a pretty standard way that's
been reinvented several times

for getting controlling the
way they talk to each other. And Carl came up with something
that was completely different.

And it took us forever. I think I was one of
the few people at FRIM who finally figured
out what it was where

he was calling a type an actor. And that is such
a strange phrase.

That threw a lot of people off. And it took me months going
back and forth with him.

And I did feed my
explanation back to him. And he said, yes, that's it. I'm not convinced
I was right yet.

But maybe he was just trying
to make me feel better. But I think that was
characteristic of his career.

Well, to be fair, didn't
he introduce the term actor before-- Yeah. --a lot of the other
stuff came along?

Yeah. Well, for him,
everything was an actor, everything could
be wheedled down

to being an actor, like,
a plus sign or something. Two is an actor. Two is an actor. Right.

I actually used that in
a project, in small talk

too as an object. So when Carl's term
that's an actor. And I needed complex arithmetic.

And I figured out how
to send the message I to a number so that--

Nice. Yes. That was a small
talk pun, I thought. That's very nice. Yeah.

And so the two was an actor
so I could send it a message.
Paul, you got your hand up.

So changing the
subject slightly. Who all remembers, Carl's belt
pack particularly in the 80?

Sure. Carl, I think, qualifies
as the original EDC guy.

So for the uninitiated,
EDC is everyday carry. And the very first
time I met Carl,

it was at some nerd
soiree in Monterey Bay. And he proudly showed--

I think it might have even
been a asilomar event. He proudly showed
me his belt pack

that included 120 feet
of piano wire in case he needed to evac out of the
third story of a building.

It wasn't clear to me whether he
actually had a descending device or if he was going
to wear gloves.

But I remember being much taken
by the forethought and sheer

nerdy practicality of Carl. It wasn't just biz. He was going to make himself
safe in a world of atoms too.

He also carried a
suitcase around with him on wheels for all of--

That was later when, I guess,
the computing equipment got to be heavier and heavier.

So what was in it,
Peter, do you remember? Well, sometimes, he opened
it up and pulled out papers.

And sometimes, it
was a computer. Sometimes, it was
other things, lunch. He had this huge
old MacBook Pro.

And I think it was
a 17 inch screen. It must have weighed, it
looked the old early portables

that-- the luggables with the
handle on it, it was that big. So he wasn't going to be
carrying that very far.

But yeah, he had tons
of papers in there. It's nice to have a big screen. Yes. You have that big screen.

He wasn't going to
replace that machine. He wasn't good at
garbage collection.

Now in the early days
at MIT, he always had a keyring with must have
been 20 or 30 keys on it.

Did he continue with
that throughout his life? Absolutely. Always had this
gigantic keyring.

I think most of those
keys, you didn't know what they were anymore
and they didn't work. Yeah. But he was probably afraid
to throw any of them out.

Yeah. Just in case. Right. Exactly. But this was before
people had master keys.

So he figured, you know,
anybody that had a lot of keys was an important person.

But that was before master keys. Now the important
person has only one key.
Like at MIT. That opens all the doors.

I remember Carl when he
got his first Newton.

And was running
around showing how paragraph converted perfectly
ordinary text into haiku.
And it was quite amazing.

The Newton of course
is a much nicer machine than we'd all admit today. But it was.

Yeah. I remember he told me,
he showed me his Newton, said, someday
you're going to have

one of these in your
future, you know, that basically everyone
was going to be

carrying around a computer. And of course, he was right. But I didn't take
it very seriously.

He's right. I got four of them
in my basement, including one of the
Siemens Newton desk phones.

It had little, you know,
telephone handle and a docking station and stuff.

Yeah. As usual, he predicted it. Well, in the last, he
did love those gadgets. I kept running into him at the
Samsung Developer Conference

at Mosconi where he seemed
very interested in the Tizen Operating System, which was
Samsung's proprietary version

of Linux, as I recall. And he was full of derision
for the way that system details

of some Linux version. I think of Linux as being
roughly similar to each other.

But he seemed to revel
in the fine points of that specific thing.

I think he may have
been going because there were these giveaways. If you registered
as a faculty, they

would give you like a watch
or something like that and he liked the gadgets.

So in his last few years,
Carl was continually talking about the HoloLens,
the Microsoft HoloLens,

and how we'd all be wearing
these smart glasses, and how that would
be everything.

And we didn't believe him. But maybe it's like we didn't

And in a few more years,

to catch on until they sell it,

you know, with the
package including some white surgical tape so

Does anybody have memories of

Tell us about the

I went to a college down the

And there were--

And we were all in awe

And he just struck me with his

been in the thick of that.

No, I meant Carl. I think his last year's
graduate student, that

was my first year in the AI
lab 'cause I didn't know him as an undergrad.

Well, I have a question. I have a question for you. Did Carl have the same

Yes.  I can't do it justice. But he did have-- he did have
that very distinctive laugh.

Very much so. I think there should be a panel

Like the Python

The same sort of

Yeah. I don't think Carl took

But he never struck me as being

But he never forgot them.

Right. That's the way he would

I mean, I think he

They were always

But I never got

Well, he spent a lot

Some of them were discovered

He may have had some friends in

But he loved that kind

Like no one else on this call.  Funny.

Funny. I also thought that he was a

Very much. But then again I might be naive. No. No, no, that's exactly right. I mean, he really felt

and the FBI, and

Department of Justice. Maybe that goes along

Well, that goes along with,

And we kept trying to

I never got traction

Right. And we've been working

And I always undermine his

And that's why I was surprised

But even there, you don't
